description: From Middle English cole, from Old English col, from Proto-West Germanic *kol, from Proto-Germanic *kulą (compare West Frisian koal, Dutch kool, German Kohle, Danish kul), from *ǵwelH- (“to burn, shine”).

Compare Old Irish gúal (“coal”), Lithuanian žvìlti (“to twinkle, glow”), Persian زغال‎ (zoğâl, “live coal”), Sanskrit ज्वल् (jval, “to burn, glow”), Tocharian B śoliye (“hearth”), all from the same root.

definitionGroups.group: (uncountable) A black or brownish black rock formed from prehistoric plant remains, composed largely of carbon and burned as a fuel.

entries.meaning: (countable) A type of coal, such as bituminous, anthracite, or lignite, and grades and varieties thereof, as a fuel commodity ready to buy and burn.
examples: Put some coal on the fire.
Order some coal from the coalyard.

entries.meaning: (countable) A piece of coal used for burning (this use is less common in American English)
examples: Put some coals on the fire.

entries.meaning: (countable) A glowing or charred piece of coal, wood, or other solid fuel.
examples: Just as the camp-fire died down to just coals, with no flames to burn the marshmallows, someone dumped a whole load of wood on, so I gave up and went to bed.

verbs.description: coal (third-person singular simple present coals, present participle coaling, simple past and past participle coaled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To take on a supply of coal (usually of steam ships).
examples: shortly after that she coaled again at Simon's Bay; and that after remaining in the neighbourhood of our ports for a time, she proceeded to Mauritius, where she coaled again, and then returned to this colony.
After the initial burn the goal of any good fire should be coaling; that is, creating a bed of solid coals that will sustain the fire.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To burn to charcoal; to char.
examples: Char-coal of roots, coaled into great pieces.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark or delineate with charcoal.
